results.title: Sense and sensibility (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Ang Lee, Lindsay Doran, Columbia Pictures and Mirage Enterprises
results.brief_description: Ang Lee directs this well scripted, acted and beautifully photographed version of Jane Austen’s first novel. Emma Thompson, (who wrote the screenplay), and Kate Winslet are Elinor and Marianne. Elinor follows her head and Marianne is guided by her heart. Both sisters eventually find love but only after the usual complications. A star-studded cast includes Hugh Grant and Alan Rickman

results.title: Sense and sensibility
results.creator_credit: Rodney Bennett, Barry Letts and BBC
results.brief_description: The story centres around two devoted sisters, Elinor, whose dignity and restraint represents “sense” and Marianne, excitable and impetuous, who represents “sensibility”. Forced by tragic circumstances to set about the delicate task of finding suitable husbands the two sisters suffer a series of disappointments and wonder if they will ever find true love and happiness. A dramatic adaptation of the novel by Jane Austen.

results.title: Video maker
results.creator_credit: Shane Yeend, Scott Young, Nine Network (Australia) and Alliance Productions
results.brief_description: Video maker is designed to help transform the confused home video operator into a budding video director. This tape looks at topics such as focus, handheld and zoom, camera editing, depth of field and exposure as well as looking at terminology, different filming techniques and equipment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Shane Yeend, Scott Young, Nine Network (Australia) and Alliance Productions

results.title: Senso daughters
results.creator_credit: Noriko Sekiguchi, Institute of Papua New Guinea Studies, Siglo Co and Tenchijin Productions
results.brief_description: Senso means “War”. “Senso daughters” is an account of the experience of Papua New Guinean and Japanese women in the South Pacific during World War II. A unique film in that it critically looks at the effect of the war not only on the indigenous culture but also on the Japanese people. Anti-war sentiment has never been tolerated within Japanese culture. For director, Noriko Sekiguchi, the film is very much a personal statement with a global message. Not only does the film critically question the war-time decisions of the late Emperor Hirohito, but it also makes public for the first time some startling information. The Japanese army took “comfort women” when they were occupying a new territory. The army prostitutes were conscripted from Korean and poor Japanese women and shipped to military bases in Rabaul.

results.title: Wind
results.creator_credit: Ivan Sen, Graeme Isaac, New South Wales Film and Television Office, ABS, SBS Independent and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
1857, The Australian Alps. Jess, a young black tracker and his elderly sergeant discover the body of a gold miner. They track the killer, an old Aboriginal man, to a cabin on a clear plateau. After losing their horse and with the sergeant in bad health they are forced to shelter in a cabin. As Jess falls asleep he is visited in his dreams by the old Aboriginal man. When Jess is faced with executing the old man he is forced to decide his fate, to choose his friend the sergeant, or to follow his ancestral soul. Cast includes Ralph Cotterill, Bradley Byqar and Steve Dodd.

results.title: Saturday night: Sunday morning [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Rima Tamou, Pauline Clague, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Australian Film Commission and New South Wales Film and Television Office
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
Based on the Archie Weller short story, this film takes us on a journey into the discontented life of Melanie as she grapples with adolescence, rural isolation and life with her dysfunctional father. Her difficulties escalate when she is taken hostage by three young men for whom life has very little meaning and actions have no consequences. Essentially a rites of passage drama, both Melanie and her captors struggle to come to terms with assumptions of difference, indigenous and non-indigenous race relations, institutionalised injustice, and loss. Cast includes Alyssa McClelland, Peter Browne and Luke Caroll.

results.title: Senator Thorpe staunchly opposes fracking in the Beetaloo
results.material_description: digital screen recording of @SenatorThorpe's Twitter, recorded with permission
results.brief_description: Greens Senator Thorpe was kicked out of Parliament after revealing a BLM shirt during her speech opposing $50 million in federal funds be granted to frack NT’s Beetaloo Basin. Thorpe demanded both Labor and the opposition listen to the people instead of selling out to gas companies that endanger Aboriginal people and Country. Thorpe was ordered to leave for violating the dress code.
results.title_for_label: Senator Thorpe staunchly opposes fracking in the Beetaloo
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Greens Senator Thorpe was kicked out of Parliament after revealing a BLM shirt during her speech opposing $50 million in federal funds be granted to frack NT’s Beetaloo Basin. Thorpe demanded both Labor and the opposition listen to the people instead of selling out to gas companies that endanger Aboriginal people and Country. Thorpe was ordered to leave for violating the dress code.
description_for_label: Greens Senator Thorpe was kicked out of Parliament after revealing a BLM shirt during her speech opposing $50 million in federal funds be granted to frack NT’s Beetaloo Basin. Thorpe demanded both Labor and the opposition listen to the people instead of selling out to gas companies that endanger Aboriginal people and Country. Thorpe was ordered to leave for violating the dress code.

results.title: Windows
results.creator_credit: Gordon Willis, Mike Lobell and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: This psycho-thriller with sexual overtones is the only directorial effort by acclaimed cinematographer Gordon Willis, who photographed many of Woody Allen’s films. Emily (Talia Shire) is a painfully introverted woman whose confidence has been further shattered by a rape attack. Her neighbour Andrea (Elizabeth Ashley), is a lesbian with a murderous past who harbours an obsessive attraction for Emily. With a highly homophobic script that provides no logic or motivation for the character’s actions, only the camerawork (by Willis) and score (by Ennio Morricone) redeem the film.
